questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of lethargy, repeated vomiting, and abdominal pain for 6 hours. Over the past 2 weeks, he has reported increased urinary frequency to his parents that they attributed to his increased oral fluid intake. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and rapid, deep breathing. Laboratory studies show the presence of acetoacetate in the urine. Which of the following cells is unable to use this molecule for energy production?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adipocytes possess the necessary enzymes to catalyze the conversion of ketone bodies to high energy phosphate molecules such as ATP and GTP.

B) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytes possess the necessary mitochondrial enzymes to catalyze the conversion of ketone bodies to high energy phosphate molecules such as ATP and GTP.

C) INCORRECT:

Neurons rely on ketone bodies to meet metabolic demands in the setting of low serum glucose. Unlike other peripheral tissues, however, neurons require at least some glucose to carry out their metabolic functions and cannot survive entirely on ketone bodies, fatty acids, and other secondary energy sources.

D) CORRECT:

Hepatocytes lack the enzyme succinyl-CoA acetoacetyl-CoA transferase (thiophorase), which is necessary for the conversion of acetoacetate to acetyl-CoA (and the downstream production of ATP and GTP from ketone bodies). Hepatocytes produce ketone bodies for use by other peripheral tissues in states of scarce serum glucose. Notably, erythrocytes cannot metabolize ketone bodies for energy either as they lack mitochondria, the site of oxidative metabolism of ketone bodies for energy production.

E) INCORRECT:

Myocytes preferentially utilize fatty acids for energy needs when there is insufficient glucose available. When ketone bodies are abundant, myocytes can utilize ketone bodies as a tertiary energy source.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) as a complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. Acetoacetate is one of the ketone bodies produced in DKA that is metabolized in the mitochondria by succinyl-CoA acetoacetyl-CoA transferase.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She takes no medications. She swims 3 times weekly and jogs several miles with her dog on most mornings. Her diet consists primarily of vegetables, fish, and whole grains; she avoids processed foods and carbohydrates. She drinks one glass of red wine with dinner on most evenings. There is no family history of serious medical illness or cardiovascular disease. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is most likely to have an increase in which of the following laboratory markers?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL), composed of triglycerides (TGs) and various apolipoproteins, including apo-CII, transports hepatic TGs from the liver to the peripheral tissues. Elevated serum levels correlate with an increased risk of atherosclerosis and most often result from a high-calorie diet rich in fats. It may also result from diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, nephrotic syndrome, or Cushing disease. In this healthy, physically active patient with moderate alcohol consumption and a diet low in fats and carbohydrates, an elevation in VLDL is unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Given this woman's healthy lifestyle, she would be expected to have high HDL and low LDL and triglyceride levels. HDL transports cholesterol from the periphery to the liver, where it is cleared from the body. As a result, HDL has protective properties against atherosclerosis and has an inverse association with coronary artery disease. Factors associated with increased HDL levels include aerobic exercise and consuming fiber, omega-3 fatty acids, and wine (HDL synthesis is increased by moderate alcohol consumption).

C) INCORRECT:

Apolipoprotein B-100 is present in very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL), low-density lipoproteins (LDL), and intermediate density lipoproteins (IDL). Elevated serum Apo B-100 levels correlate with an increased risk of atherosclerosis and most often result from an unhealthy lifestyle, including a diet high in calories and fats. An increase may also be seen in diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, nephrotic syndrome, cholestasis, and Cushing disease. In this healthy, physically active patient with a healthy diet, an elevation in apolipoprotein B-100 is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Triglycerides (TGs) are composed of one glycerol linked to three fatty acids. In addition to familial hypertriglyceridemia, high triglyceride levels are associated with obesity, diabetes mellitus, consumption of a high-calorie diet, and heavy alcohol use. This patient's active lifestyle and moderate alcohol use are more likely to result in a low triglyceride level and an increase in a different laboratory marker.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) transports cholesterol from the liver to the peripheral tissues. It contains cholesterol, triglycerides, phospholipids, and apolipoprotein B-100 as well as apo-CIII. Elevated serum LDL levels correlate with an increased risk of atherosclerosis and most often result from an unhealthy lifestyle, including a diet rich in fats and carbohydrates. In this healthy, physically active patient, an elevation of LDL is unlikely.
questions.hint: This woman leads a very healthy lifestyle (e.g., frequent exercise, diet low in fats and carbohydrates) and is expected to have elevation in a lab marker that has protective effects against atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy with a seizure disorder is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of vomiting and lethargy. Laboratory studies show a decreased serum glucose concentration. Further testing confirms a deficiency in an enzyme involved in triglyceride synthesis that is normally found in the liver but not in adipose tissue. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyl-CoA dehydrogenases catalyze the initial step of β-oxidation by converting fatty acyl-CoA into acetyl-CoA. This group of enzymes is found in all mitochondria-containing cells, including adipocytes.
Image Description:

Acetyl-CoA is metabolized within hepatocytes to produce ketone bodies (i.e., acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through the process of ketogenesis. The lack of thiophorase in hepatocytes prevents the consumption of ketone bodies within the liver. During states of ketosis, excess acetoacetate undergoes spontaneous decarboxylation into acetone, a volatile organic acid that can be eliminated through the respiratory system.

B) INCORRECT:

Glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis that reversibly converts dihydroxyacetone phosphate to glycerol-3-phosphate. This enzyme is found in most tissues including adipose tissue.

C) CORRECT:

Triglycerides are a component of the cell membrane and are required for transporting fatty acids via blood to various tissues. Triglycerides are formed by the combination of three fatty acids with glycerol-3-phosphate (G3P). The first pathway for G3P generation involves glycerol kinase, which phosphorylates free glycerol using ATP. This enzyme traps and recycles free glycerol released by adipolysis and lipoprotein metabolism. The second pathway involves glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, which reversibly converts dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DAP) using NADH to G3P. Hepatocytes have both these enzymes but adipocytes lack glycerol kinase and can generate G3P only via one pathway, i.e., by utilizing DAP.

DAP is an intermediate product of both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. The conversion of G3P to DAP in the liver by glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase is necessary for approx. 20% of gluconeogenesis. If G3P cannot be synthesized from glycerol, an increased proportion of DAP is diverted for G3P production to maintain triglyceride synthesis. As a result of DAP diversion, gluconeogenesis is decreased and hypoglycemia can occur when glucose utilization is increased (e.g., during physical stress, infections).
Image Description:

Chylomicrons and VLDLs are lipoproteins that are particularly rich in triglycerides/triacylglycerols (TAGs). They carry TAGs from ingested food or the liver to the adipocytes, where membranous lipoprotein lipases (LPLs) break down the TAGs into free fatty acids, glycerol, and lipoprotein remnants.

The free fatty acids enter the cell by means of fatty acid transport proteins (FATPs), which also have an acyl-CoA synthetase activity (here shown in two steps). The resulting acyl-CoA and glycerol-3-phosphate (from glycolysis) are esterified into TAGs again.

To a lesser extent, acetyl-CoA generated in glycolysis also contributes to the intracellular synthesis of fatty acids and, thus, of TAGs.

GLUT4 = glucose transporter 4; GAP = glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate; DAP = dihydroxyacetone phosphate

D) INCORRECT:

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase converts acetyl-CoA into malonyl-CoA during the rate-limiting step of fatty acid biosynthesis. This enzyme is found in most tissues including adipose tissue, with higher concentrations in fat-synthesizing organs.

E) INCORRECT:

HMG-CoA reductase catalyzes the rate-limiting step of cholesterol biosynthesis by catabolizing HMG-CoA into mevalonic acid. This enzyme is found in most tissues including adipose tissue.
questions.hint: This class of enzymes catalyzes the transfer of a phosphate group from a high-energy molecule.

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy with cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician by his parents for a 3-week history of bulky, oily, foul-smelling stools. He is at the 5th percentile for height and 6th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows sparse hair growth and a generalized dry, scaly rash. A diagnosis of essential fatty acid malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is made. Nutritional supplementation along with pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy is planned. If enzyme replacement therapy is initiated with amylase and protease but without adding pancrelipase, synthesis of which of the following substances is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Even in patients with fatty acid malabsorption, nonessential fatty acids, such as lauric acid, can be synthesized endogenously from amino acids or carbohydrates via acetyl CoA.

B) INCORRECT:

Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) is a cofactor in fatty acid synthesis but is not a fatty acid derivative. Although small amounts of vitamin B5 can be synthesized by the intestinal microbiota, humans cannot synthesize vitamin B5 endogenously (only vitamins B3 and D can be synthesized by the body). Also, intact pancreatic exocrine function is not necessary for vitamin B5 absorption and is only critical for the absorption of vitamin B12 and the fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K).

C) INCORRECT:

Even in patients with fatty acid malabsorption, nonessential fatty acids, such as palmitoleic acid, can be synthesized endogenously from amino acids or carbohydrates via acetyl CoA.

D) CORRECT:

Nonessential fatty acids (e.g., lauric acid, palmitic acid, palmitoleic acid) can be synthesized from amino acids, carbohydrates, and other fatty acids. Unlike nonessential fatty acids, essential fatty acids cannot be synthesized endogenously and must be obtained through dietary intake. Essential fatty acids are polyunsaturated fatty acids and include linoleic acid, an essential omega-6 fatty acid, and alpha-linolenic acid, an essential omega-3 fatty acid. Arachidonic acid is a direct derivative of linoleic acid and cannot be synthesized from other fatty acids.

Fatty acid malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is a common complication in patients with cystic fibrosis and can manifest with steatorrhea, failure to thrive, and essential fatty acid deficiency. This patient's scaly dermatitis, alopecia, and growth failure are characteristic of essential fatty acid deficiency. Fatty acid malabsorption may also be seen in patients with autoimmune diseases (e.g., celiac sprue, Crohn disease), gastrointestinal infections (e.g., giardiasis, Whipple disease), and after extensive bowel resection.

E) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinic acid, which is an intermediate in the urea cycle, is a basic nonproteinogenic amino acid derived from aspartate and citrulline. Argininosuccinic acid synthesis is unlikely to be affected by fatty acid malabsorption.
questions.hint: Pancreatic lipase (pancrelipase) breaks down triglycerides into monoglycerides and free fatty acids, which can then be absorbed by the gastrointestinal tract. If a patient with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is treated with amylase and protease without adding pancrelipase, their absorption of carbohydrates and amino acids will improve while fatty acid malabsorption will continue. Some fatty acids can be synthesized endogenously while others can only be obtained through dietary intake.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with long-standing type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and diffuse abdominal pain. She has been unable to administer her usual insulin doses for the past 24 hours. Laboratory studies reveal significantly elevated levels of acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate. Which of the following is the rate-determining enzyme in generating these molecules?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase, which catalyzes the ATP-dependent carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, is the rate-determining step in fatty acid synthesis, not ketogenesis.

B) CORRECT:

Ketogenesis occurs primarily in the liver, and this mitochondrial metabolic pathway helps channel acetyl-CoA into ketone body production to provide energy for the brain and muscles when glucose is unavailable. The mitochondrial isozyme form of HMG-CoA synthase (3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA synthase) catalyzes the rate-limiting step of ketogenesis. During prolonged fasting or uncontrolled type 1 diabetes mellitus, insulin levels fall while glucagon levels rise. This hormonal shift increases the activity and expression of HMG-CoA synthase, which combines acetoacetyl-CoA with acetyl-CoA to form HMG-CoA (see “Overview of rate-limiting enzymes” table).

Key learning point: The rate-limiting step of ketogenesis is mitochondrial HMG-CoA synthase.
Image Description:

Acetyl-CoA is metabolized within hepatocytes to produce ketone bodies (i.e., acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through the process of ketogenesis. The lack of thiophorase in hepatocytes prevents the consumption of ketone bodies within the liver. During states of ketosis, excess acetoacetate undergoes spontaneous decarboxylation into acetone, a volatile organic acid that can be eliminated through the respiratory system.

C) INCORRECT:

Acetoacetate can undergo spontaneous decarboxylation to form acetone; acetoacetate decarboxylase accelerates this minor side reaction. This non-regulatory step produces acetone, which cannot be used for energy.

D) INCORRECT:

β-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase converts acetoacetate to β-hydroxybutyrate and vice versa. It is involved in ketogenesis and helps maintain the balance between the two main ketone bodies but is not the rate-limiting enzyme.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is the rate-limiting enzyme of the hexose monophosphate pathway. It catalyzes the oxidation of glucose-6-phosphate while reducing NADP+ to NADPH. Although NADPH is essential for reductive biosynthesis, G6PD plays no direct role in ketone body synthesis.
questions.hint: Acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate are ketone bodies, which are produced in excess in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a routine examination. She takes no medications. She swims three times per week and jogs most mornings with her dog. Her diet is mainly vegetables, fish, and whole grains, and she avoids processed foods and carbohydrates. She drinks one glass of red wine with dinner most evenings. There is no family history of serious medical illness or cardiovascular disease. Physical examination is normal. This patient is most likely to have an increase in which one of the following laboratory markers?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) transports cholesterol from the liver to the peripheral tissues. It contains cholesterol, triglycerides, phospholipids, and apolipoprotein B-100 as well as apo-CIII. Elevated serum LDL levels correlate with an increased risk of atherosclerosis and most often result from an unhealthy lifestyle, including a diet rich in fats and carbohydrates. In this healthy, physically active patient, an elevation of LDL is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL), composed of triglycerides (TGs) and various apolipoproteins, including apo-CII, transports hepatic TGs from the liver to the peripheral tissues. Elevated serum levels correlate with an increased risk of atherosclerosis and most often result from a high-calorie diet rich in fats. It may also result from diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, nephrotic syndrome, or Cushing disease. In this healthy, physically active patient with moderate alcohol consumption and a diet low in fats and carbohydrates, an elevation in VLDL is unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Apolipoprotein B-100 is present in very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL), low-density lipoproteins (LDL), and intermediate density lipoproteins (IDL). Elevated serum Apo B-100 levels correlate with an increased risk of atherosclerosis and most often result from an unhealthy lifestyle, including a diet high in calories and fats. An increase may also be seen in diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, nephrotic syndrome, cholestasis, and Cushing disease. In this healthy, physically active patient with a healthy diet, an elevation in apolipoprotein B-100 is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Triglycerides (TGs) are composed of one glycerol linked to three fatty acids. In addition to familial hypertriglyceridemia, high triglyceride levels are associated with obesity, diabetes mellitus, consumption of a high-calorie diet, and heavy alcohol use. This patient's active lifestyle and moderate alcohol use are more likely to result in a low triglyceride level and an increase in a different laboratory marker.

E) CORRECT:

Given this woman's healthy lifestyle, she would be expected to have high HDL and low LDL and triglyceride levels. HDL transports cholesterol from the periphery to the liver, where it is cleared from the body. As a result, HDL has protective properties against atherosclerosis and has an inverse association with coronary artery disease. Factors associated with increased HDL levels include aerobic exercise and consuming fiber, omega-3 fatty acids, and wine (HDL synthesis is increased by moderate alcohol consumption).

Key learning point: A healthy lifestyle with regular exercise, a balanced diet, and moderate alcohol intake is associated with increased high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels, which are protective against atherosclerosis.
questions.hint: This woman leads a very healthy lifestyle (e.g., frequent exercise, diet low in fats and carbohydrates) and is expected to have elevation in a lab marker that has protective effects against atherosclerosis.
